title: What are the music similarities and differences of Thailand and Indonesia? - Quora

response.answer_text: The first thing we must establish is the immense diversity of music within Indonesia alone—the gamelan orchestras of Java and Bali are much more similar to Thailand’s phipat music than it is to, say, sasando music of Rote Island or even Angklung music of the Sunda people (who share an island with the Javanese). So I’m using the description ‘Indonesian music’ as an umbrella term for the most widely spread traditional and folk music typologies that belong to cultures that happened to fall under Indonesia’s current geopolitical borders. As with many Austronesian cultures, both Thai and Indonesian music feature percussions (non-melodic ones like various forms of drums and melodic ones, usually metallophones like the Indonesian gamelan or Thai ranat). They also both have string instruments like the kecapi in Indonesia or khim in Thailand (though one is plucked and the other is struck). The most striking difference I can think of is Arab influence in more modern versions of Indonesian folk music. Speaking of more modern music, my take is that both Thai and Indonesian music makers have a knack for making sappy and mawkish pop-ballad songs :)

The similarities is that we have folk and traditional music. The differences is from the traditional music instruments and also kinda styles from the music itself. Thai have Isan style, Indonesia have dangdut. Thai have ranad, Indonesia have gamelan. Please take sometimes to listen those music, you'll find out the difference easily. The complete answer is on your fingers and ears.
